On roads with 2 lanes in each direction, two-wheelers may ride in the left lane during heavy traffic

When you want to change lanes, you must check that the lane to be engaged is clear in front for a sufficient distance

When traveling on a one-way roadway, the left turn is made by signaling in advance the maneuver to be made

Running by parallel rows is allowed when authorized by traffic officials

Arriving in the vicinity of an intersection you must prepare to observe the rules of precedence

Arriving at an intersection you are allowed to engage it only if you have the ability to go ahead and clear it

Arriving in the vicinity of an intersection you must quickly overtake to the left if you want to turn right
Arriving near an intersection in built-up areas, it is necessary to sound the horn

Reversing is not allowed in the vicinity or at intersections

When exiting with a vehicle from private property, you must give right of way to any pedestrians

When exiting with a vehicle from private property, it is mandatory to sound the horn
When exiting with a vehicle from private property, you have the right of way over pedestrians

Drivers intending to overtake must ensure that visibility is such that they can maneuver
A driver intending to overtake must ensure that the maneuver can be accomplished without constituting an obstruction
A driver intending to overtake must ensure that the driver ahead in the same lane has not signaled that he or she intends to perform a similar maneuver
The driver intending to overtake must ensure that the driver following him on the same roadway has not initiated the overtaking
The driver intending to overtake must ensure that the road is clear to allow the overtaking to be fully executed
The driver intending to overtake must also assess the space required for the maneuver in relation to the speed difference between his own vehicle and the vehicle to be overtaken
A driver intending to overtake must take into account any vehicles coming from the opposite direction
Drivers intending to overtake must estimate the space required in relation to the length of their vehicle and the vehicle to be overtaken
A driver intending to overtake must ensure that the width of the roadway allows for safe maneuvering
A driver intending to overtake must ensure that no vertical sign prohibits the maneuver
Drivers intending to overtake should simply make sure that no vehicles are coming from the opposite direction
The driver who intends to overtake has the sole obligation to operate the turn signal (arrows)
The driver intending to overtake should only make sure that there is no overtaking prohibition sign
Before starting an overtaking maneuver, the turn signal must be operated.
The overtaking maneuver is normally carried out to the left
Overtaking is done by keeping an adequate lateral distance from the overtaking vehicle
After making an overtaking maneuver, the driver of the vehicle must move back to the right as soon as possible without creating danger or hindrance
The driver of the vehicle being overtaken must facilitate the overtaking maneuver and not accelerate
The driver of the vehicle being overtaken, on roads with one lane in each direction, should keep as close as possible to the right-hand edge
The overtaking maneuver should not be performed if there is insufficient visible space to complete it safely
The overtaking maneuver should not be performed if the roadway is not wide enough
The driver who intends to overtake is obliged to operate the audible signal
A driver who intends to initiate an overtaking maneuver is not required to operate the turn signal
After overtaking, the vehicle may immediately move to the right if it cuts into the path of the overtaken vehicle
The driver of the overtaken vehicle may compete in speed with the driver of the vehicle that is overtaking him or her
The overtaking maneuver is carried out even if there is insufficient visible space to complete it safely

After performing an initial overtaking maneuver, on roads with at least two lanes in each direction, it is possible to perform another overtaking maneuver without turning back to the right, if you do not create an obstruction
The overtaking maneuver must be performed to the right if the driver of the vehicle to be overtaken has signaled an intention to turn left
The overtaking maneuver must be performed to the right if, on a one-way road, the driver of the vehicle to be overtaken has signaled an intention to pull over to the left
The streetcar overtaking maneuver can take place on both sides if the road is one-way and the width of the roadway allows it
If the streetcar or trolleybus is stopped, the overtaking maneuver can be made to the right if there is a lifesaver
If the streetcar or trolleybus is stopped, the overtaking maneuver cannot take place on the right side if the lifesaver is missing
If the streetcar or trolleybus is stopped for passengers to board and alight, the overtaking maneuver can always be performed on the right
It is always prohibited to make the overtaking maneuver to the right
The overtaking maneuver can, as a rule, be made to the right on highways
The overtaking maneuver may be made to the left only if the vehicle to be overtaken is turning right
It is forbidden to make a second overtake without first moving back to the right
Overtaking is prohibited near curves on two-lane two-way roads
Overtaking is prohibited near speed bumps on two-lane two-way roads
Overtaking is prohibited in poor visibility
Overtaking is allowed on curves if the road has two separate carriageways with at least two lanes in each direction
Overtaking is allowed over speed bumps if the road has two separate carriageways and two lanes in each direction
It is prohibited to overtake a vehicle that is overtaking another if this requires moving to the side reserved for the other direction of travel
It is prohibited to overtake stopped vehicles at level crossings, if you have to engage the opposite semi-lane
It is prohibited to overtake slow-moving vehicles at level crossings when, for this purpose it is necessary to move to the side reserved for the other direction of travel
Overtaking vehicles stopped at traffic lights is prohibited when, for this purpose it is necessary to move to the side reserved for the other direction of travel
It is prohibited to overtake slow-moving vehicles due to traffic congestion when, for this purpose it is necessary to move to the side reserved for the other direction of travel
Overtaking is allowed at or near intersections if regulated by traffic lights
It is permissible to overtake on the right at intersections regulated by traffic lights if the vehicle to be overtaken has indicated that it wants to turn left and has initiated the maneuver
Overtaking is allowed at intersections if the road has a right of way as long as it has two separate carriageways and the lanes are delimited by the appropriate road markings
Overtaking is allowed at intersections if you overtake a non-motorized two-wheeled vehicle and do not encroach on the side reserved for the opposite direction
